metadata.title: Comparative investigation of small laccase immobilized on carbon nanomaterials for direct bioelectrocatalysis of oxygen reduction

Comparative investigation of small laccase immobilized on carbon nanomaterials for direct bioelectrocatalysis of oxygen reduction Zhongjie Hana,b,c,d, Lijun Zhaob,c,d, Ping Yub,c,d, Jiwen Chena,⁎, Fei Wub,c,d,⁎⁎, Lanqun Maob,c,d a Central Iron & Steel Research Institute, Beijing 100081, China b Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Science, Key Laboratory of Analytical Chemistry for Living Biosystems, Institute of Chemistry, the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), Beijing 100190, China cUniversity of CAS, Beijing 100049, China d CAS Research/Education Center for Excellence in Molecule Science, Beijing 100190, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Small laccase Carbon nanomaterials Oxygen reduction Direct electron transfer
A B S T R A C T
In this study, different carbon nanomaterials (carbon nanotubes, solid carbon spheres and graphene nanosheets) for immobilizing bacterial small laccase (SLAC) to enable direct bioelectrocatalysis of oxygen reduction were comparatively investigated. Highest bioelectrocatalytic current response was achieved with ethanol-assisted SLAC adsorption on single-walled carbon nanotubes. Direct electron transfer (DET) rates were determined and generally shown to be larger with carbon nanomaterials in smaller dimensions or higher surface curvature, i.e., 1.92, 1.05, 1.52, 0.62 and 0.63 s−1 for adsorbed SLAC on single-walled carbon nanotubes (d= ca. 1.5 nm), double-walled carbon nanotubes (d= 2–4 nm), thinner multi-walled carbon nanotubes (d= 8–15 nm), thicker multi-walled carbon nanotubes (d= 20–30 nm) and graphene nanosheets, respectively. No obvious catalytic current response was obtained with solid carbon spheres (d > 200 nm). Surface nanostructures on electrodes with decreased cylindrical diameter could enable a favorable protein orientation of immobilized SLAC for efficient electronic communication between the catalytic copper sites and carbon nanomaterials as revealed by surface vibrational spectroscopy. Moreover, such a difference in DET kinetics of SLAC could be an outcome of synergic effects of surface properties (curvature, oxygen-containing groups, etc.) and conductivity of carbon nanomaterials. It is expected to offer useful information to fabricating carbon-based oxygen-reducing biocathodes of wide working pH range and high tolerance to chloride.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Small laccase (SLAC) originated from bacteria has emerged as a new blue multicopper bioelectrocatalyst for fabricating four-electron oxygen reducing biocathodes [1–7]. Compared to the extensively explored eukaryotic laccase and bilirubin oxidase, SLAC exhibits advantages in wider working pH range and much higher tolerance to halogen ions [1], allowing the development of biofuel cells adapted to salty (sea water) or physiological (body fluid) conditions. Each SLAC monomer carries a T1 Cu and an oxygen-reducing T2/T3 Cu cluster, and two of them are dimerized into a catalytically active form with T1 Cu quite close to the protein surface while T2/T3 Cu cluster located at the dimerization interface [8]. Therefore, SLAC is expected to enable direct electron transfer (DET) between the T1 Cu site and electrode surface in no need of redox mediators.
In DET configurations with enzymatic bioelectrocatalysts, carbon nanomaterials have been the hot spot because of their superior conductivity and surface controllability. By regulation of carbon size, morphology, hydrophobicity and chemistry, enzyme-surface interactions can be directed in a DET-favorable fashion [9]. In recent years, several research groups have reported the fabrication of mediatorless biocathodes with SLAC and carbon nanotubes or graphites [2–7]. Hydrophobic interactions between aromatic residues near T1 Cu and πconjugated carbonaceous surfaces help orientate SLAC molecules [4,9]. In this work, we extended the exploration of SLAC performance on a set of carbon nanomaterials of different morphologies, including two-dimensional and three-dimensional substrates. sections.heading: 2. Experiment
sections.text: Expression plasmids was constructed by cloning the DNA sequence encoding SLAC from Streptomyces coelicolor into pET20b vector and synthesized by Genescript Co. Ltd. (Nanjing, China). Recombinant SLAC was overexpressed and purified according to the procedure by Machczynski et al. [1]. The concentration of the SLAC solution used in the experiments was 13.5mg/mL and the activity of the SLAC solution used in the experiment was 14.4 U/mL or 1.1 U/mg. Single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) were purchased from Shenzhen Nanoport Co., Ltd. (Shenzhen, China). Double-walled carbon nanotubes (DWCNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were purchased from DK Nanotechnology Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China). Prior to use, all carbon nanotubes were purified by re-fluxing in 2.6M nitric acid for 5 h followed by centrifugation, washing, and air-drying to evaporate the solvent, and finally heated under vacuum at 500 °C for 2 h before use. Graphene (> 95% purity) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Solid carbon spheres were prepared according to the published procedure [10].

sections.heading: 2.1. Bioelectrode preparation and characterization
sections.text:
Glassy carbon electrodes (GCEs, diameter: 3 mm, CHI Instruments) were pre-polished with alumina slurry (0.3 μm and 0.05 μm) on a polishing cloth and cleaned by sonication in ethanol and deionized water. Carbon nanomaterials were dispersed in ethanol under sonication to get a uniform suspension (1mg/mL), 5 μL of which was coated onto each GCE by drop-casting and dried under a hot incandescent lamp for 1 to 2 h. SLAC solution were pre-mixed on vortex with 20% ethanol for 15min at room temperature. After that, another 10 μL of the SLACethanol mixture was pipetted onto the carbon-modified GCE. All electrodes were dried under ambient air at room temperature before measurements for 3 to 4 h. All electrodes were washed gently with 1mL sodium acetate buffer (0.1M, pH 6) before use to rinse down loosely attached SLAC. The amount of adsorbed SLAC on the electrode surface was then determined by measuring the amount of SLAC rinsed down by bicinchoninic acid (BCA) assay.
Cyclic voltammetry (0.6 V to −0.1 V, 10mV/s, 2 cycles) was conducted in a three-electrode set-up controlled by a potentiostat (Autolab PGSTAT302). SLAC‑carbon GCEs, Pt wire and Ag/AgCl electrode (KClsaturated) were used as the working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. Sodium acetate buffer (0.1M, pH 6.0) was used as the supporting electrolyte. N2 or O2-saturated solution was prepared by purging with high-purity N2 or O2 gas for 30min before test.

sections.heading: 2.2. Electron transfer rate calculation
sections.text: Heterogeneous electron transfer kinetics between the adsorbed SLAC molecules and the conductive surface was investigated by cyclic voltammetry at different scan rates (5mV/s–100mV/s until peak potential separation> 0.2 V) and rate constants were estimated according to the Laviron formula with n and α being 4 and 0.6 [4,11]. When determining the Ep of the reduction current, the second-order derivative was taken after smoothing the reduction current curve with the enzyme-free background subtracted.

sections.heading: 2.3. Conformational characterization of immobilized SLAC
sections.text:
Surface protein characterization by attenuated total reflectance infrared (ATR-IR) spectroscopy and spectral analysis were conducted according to our previous method [12]. Briefly, 5 μL of carbon nanomaterials in ethanol was drop-coated and dried on calcium fluoride slides, followed by layering another 10 μL of SLAC solution containing
20% ethanol. Control slides without enzymes were also prepared for background subtraction. All slides were first dried at ambient air and then in vacuum overnight. ATR-IR spectra were collected from 500 to 4000 cm−1 and processed in OMNIC. Component peak positions in the Amide I region (1700–1600 cm−1) were assigned by fourth-derivative IR spectra and resolved by Gaussian fitting with the band width set to 8 cm−1.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
Our previous research showed that water-miscible organic solvents such as ethanol can affect the orientation of the fungus laccase on carbon nanotubes and bring T1 Cu closer to the electrode surface, thereby increasing the efficiency of DET [12]. In order to prove whether this method was still applicable to the immobilization of SLAC, we introduced 20% ethanol into the casting solution of SLAC that was dropcoated on the single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT)-modified GCE. Direct bioelectrocatalysis of oxygen reduction by the untreated or ethanol-treated SLAC-SWCNT GCEs was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in 0.1M sodium acetate buffer (pH 6.0). In the oxygenated solution, oxygen reductive current emerged at an onset potential of ca. 0.3 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) and reached the maxima at 0.1 V for both types of SLAC electrodes. Notably, this measured formal potential of T1 Cu in SLAC (ca. 0.5 V vs. NHE) is lower than that of fungus laccases (0.78 V vs. NHE) [13] and bilirubin oxidase (0.8 V vs. NHE) [14]. Nevertheless, SLAC is advantageous in its much stronger tolerance to harsh conditions (alkaline pH or high halide concentration). The control SLAC-GCE without ethanol treatment produced a maximum turnover current of only 0.5 μA (non-catalytic background current subtracted, Fig. 1A). In comparison, the ethanol-treated SLAC-SWCNT GCE displayed faster DET kinetics in terms of a steeper current increase at low overpotential region (0.3 V–0.2 V), and higher maximum catalytic current of 1.0 μA (Fig. 1B). This suggests a larger population of enzymes with favorable orientation induced by surface wetting effect of ethanol.
Using this immobilization means, we compared bioelectrocatalytic performance of SLAC on the three-dimensional SWCNTs and two-dimensional graphene nanosheets (SLAC-graphene GCE). As the former exhibited a maximum turnover current of ca. 0.85 μA in air-saturated buffer (Fig. 1C), SLAC-graphene GCE under the same condition was slower in DET rate (relatively retarded current increase in Fig. 1D) with dramatically decreased catalytic current (0.25 μA at 0.11 V). Such a difference in current response was assumed to be the result of different surface curvatures of immobilizing platforms, considering SWCNTs (~1.5 nm in diameter) as rolled-up graphene nanosheets. The distance between T1 Cu of SLAC and the curved surface of SWCNTs may be shorter to promote DET, as compared to longer separation on flat surfaces.
In order to testify our assumption that the intensity of catalytic oxygen reduction current of SLAC-modified electrode was related to the surface curvature of carbon nanomaterials, we further examined DWCNT (2–4 nm in diameter), thinner MWCNT-1 (8–15 nm in diameter), thicker MWCNT-2 (20–30 nm in diameter) and solid carbon sphere (> 200 nm in diameter). Taken results in Figs. 1C and 2 together, bioelectrocatalytic current of oxygen reduction at 0.08 V (under air-saturated condition) decreased as the cylindrical or spherical diameter increased in the order of SWCNT (0.85 μA) > DWCNT (0.5 μA) > MWCNT-1 (0.2 μA) > MWCNT-2 (0.12 μA) > solid carbon sphere (no obvious catalytic current). Analysis of the adsorption capacity of these carbon nanomaterials excluded the possibility that variation in the surface amount of SLAC led to the difference in catalytic current response, as adsorbed SLAC molecules were in almost the same amount for tested carbon substrates (Table 1) except for MWCNT2 which exhibited a lower adsorption capacity. The observed trend implied a better electronic communication between T1 Cu of SLAC and conductive surfaces of higher curvature with respect to the size of enzyme molecules (14 nm in diameter on average as determined by
dynamic light scattering). Kinetics of heterogeneous electron transfer during oxygen reduction was quantified in terms of apparent electron transfer rate constant (k0′), which can be calculated by Butler–Volmer [15] or Laviron formalism [4,11]. A linear dependency of the peak current on the potential scan rate was drawn (data not shown) to confirm the surface-controlled electrochemical process with T1 Cu in direct contact with the electrode, which was demonstrated to be a 1 e−/1H+ transfer reaction [4]. Hence, Laviron treatment was employed to assess k0′ between the copper sites in the monolayer of surface adsorbed SLAC molecules and carbon substrates during an irreversible turnover. It should be noted that measurements for kinetic analysis were done in oxygenated conditions, so intramolecular electron transfer (T1 to T2/T3 Cu) coupled by oxygen reduction reaction (total number of e− transferred in a single turnover is 4) would also affect the current outcome. However, this would not likely cause changes of k0′ unless the adsorbed SLAC underwent significant unfolding or inactivation. All variations in k0′ can be ascribed to electron dynamics across the heterogeneous SLAC/electrode interface. As can be seen, heterogeneous DET rate generally decreased as the cylindrical diameter increased, which could reflect elongated distance between the electron donor (conductive surface) and electron acceptor (coppers in SLAC) according to Marcus theory [16]. For SWCNTs (1.92 s−1), DWCNTs (1.05 s−1) and thinner MWCNTs (1.52 s−1) in smaller cylindrical diameters, they may obtain more chances of docking with SLAC by surface complementarity and hydrophobic interactions with residues in the cavity of SLAC accommodating T1 Cu, thus decreasing spatial barrier for DET. In contrast, SLAC might undergo non-directed weak interactions with flattened surface of thicker MWCNTs (0.63 s−1), graphene nanosheets (0.64 s−1) and solid carbon spheres (no observable catalytic current) during physical adsorption and adopt random orientations.
Knowing that the surface-protein interaction determines its function in immobilized state, then we performed structural analysis of immobilized SLAC on above-mentioned carbon nanomaterials by attenuated total reflectance infrared (ATR-IR) spectroscopy. Films of SWCNTs, DWCNTs, MWCNTs-1, MWCNTs-2, graphene or solid carbon sphere containing adsorbed SLAC molecules were characterized to provide the difference IR spectra (enzyme-free background subtracted). The Amide I region (1700–1600 cm−1) was selected for peak analysis, because merged peaks in this region are formed by the stretching vibration of C]O bonds in amide linkages, whose frequency can well reflect the secondary structures in the protein skeleton [17]. Due to extensive peak overlaps in Amide I area, difference IR spectra were subjected to second- and fourth-derivative processing for peak separation by Gauss algorithm. According to the literature records [18] and our fourth-derivative results obtained in the experiment, the secondary structures of immobilized SLAC with their respective component peaks can be divided into five types, named turns (1667 ± 1, 1675 ± 1, 1680 ± 2 and 1685 ± 2 cm−1), α-helices (1656 ± 2 cm−1), random coils (1648 ± 3 cm−1), β-sheets (1692 ± 2 cm−1) and low-frequency (LF) β-sheets (1606 ± 2, 1615 ± 2 and 1622 ± 2 cm−1). Peak areas were integrated to yield relative ratios of secondary structures on tested carbon nanomaterials.
Fig. 3A presents resolved fractions of different secondary structures in immobilized SLAC. Since SLAC is mainly composed by an anti-parallel β-barrel [8], the compositional change of β-sheets is an important sign of the conformation and molecular orientation of the enzyme. It can be seen that the contents of regular β-sheets were better reserved in SLAC on SWCNTs (40.35 ± 0.41%), DWCNTs (41.21 ± 0.65%), MWCNTs-1 (44.39 ± 0.86%) and MWCNTs-2 (42.20 ± 0.10%), as compared to the low ratios with graphene (39.18 ± 1.03%) and solid carbon spheres (36.79 ± 0.23%). On the contrary, the structural ratio
changes in the low frequency region followed a reversed trend of higher LF β-sheets in SLAC on surfaces of lower curvature. These LF β-sheets were given rise by deformation of the major body of enzymes upon immobilization. Significant decreases in all other four types of secondary structures also supported this reason. Interestingly, the changing trend of regular β-sheets on curved surfaces did not well match the order of catalytic current change. As it shows, the ratio of regular βsheets leveled up as the tube diameter increased and reached the maxima with MWCNTs-1. The most plausible explanation for the loss of regular β-sheets without obvious gaining of LF β-sheets on surfaces of higher curvature may be the enhanced hydrophobic interactions with small β fragments surrounding T1 Cu in SLAC, turning them into β-turns.
Combining both CV and ATR-IR results, we can draw a picture of immobilized SLAC on carbon nanomaterials, illustrating the role of surface curvature in determining the molecular orientation of enzymes and direct bioelectrocatalytic performance. As depicted in Fig. 3B, SLAC molecules tend to adopt the “standing” orientation on thinner carbon nanotubes (e.g. SWCNTs) with T1 Cu sites facing toward the conductive surface, which is facilitated by promoted hydrophobic interactions with aromatic residues in the groove at the dimerizing interface of SLAC. In this case, electrons can be efficiently transferred to T1 Cu and then T2/T3 Cu cluster with the majority of the anti-parallel β-barrel unaffected by immobilization. As the carbon nanomaterial is sized up and its relative surface flatness improved, hydrophobic interactions are weakened due to shape mismatching. The resulting orientation of SLAC molecules appears to be in a more random manner. The population of “lying” enzymes with the side of the β-barrel facing surfaces becomes larger on GD and solid carbon spheres, leading to smaller catalytic current response as DET between T1 Cu and the electrode is hindered. It is worth mentioning that the changing trend of heterogeneous electron transfer kinetics (k0) did not strictly accord with that of the regular β-sheet ratio in adsorbed SLAC. In addition to probable decreased electronic transmission distance, electronic conductivity of carbon nanomaterials also affects DET efficiency. Notably, structural entity of SLAC was best reserved on MWCNT-1, but the corresponding DET rate was smaller than that with SWCNT, which could be explained by different conducting properties of SWCNTs (ballistic conductor) and MWCNTs (diffusive conductor) [19]. Moreover, material surface chemistry is another important factor that cannot
be neglected in regulating surface-protein interactions. Surface oxygencontaining moieties of carbon nanotubes like hydroxyls and carboxyls after strong acid treatment might also assist in optimizing immobilization orientation, either by electrostatically repelling negatively charge regions of SLAC (mostly carrying negative charges except the hydrophobic cavity [1]) or by interactions with T1 Cu at its secondcoordination sphere.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In conclusion, we have conducted a comparative investigation of direct bioelectrocatalysis of oxygen reduction by SLAC on carbon nanomaterials of diverse properties. As we have found, catalytic current response is enhanced by higher surface curvature relative to the size of SLAC molecule (a maximally 2.4-fold current increase from flat nanosheets to curved nanotubes with accordingly 2-fold increase in DET rate constant), and the best bioelectrocatalytic performance has been obtained with SLAC physically adsorbed on SWCNTs. Vibrational spectroscopic studies further supply the structural insights into the enzyme conformation and orientation under the influence of the changing surface curvatures. Our results show that the SLAC molecules in the “standing” orientation are favored on carbon nanomaterials in smaller sizes and higher surface curvatures to thereby facilitate more DET events during bioelectrocatalysis. Quantitative proof provided by
calculation of heterogeneous electron transfer rate demonstrates that DET efficiency is an outcome of synergistic effect of morphological, conducting and chemical properties of carbon nanomaterials. This study is anticipated to provide a new way of designing nanostructured bioelectrochemical interfaces with lower uncertainty of enzyme orientation and enhanced direct bioelectrocatalytic performance.
